DOCNAME: CASE OF KRONE VERLAG GmbH & Co. KG (No. 3) v. AUSTRIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses (domestic proceedings) - claim dismissed;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG , a limited liability company with its registered office in GPE , is the owner of the DATE newspaper ORG published by ORG Zeitungs- und ORG ( “ the publisher ” ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the GPE edition of the PERSON published an advertisement for subscriptions to the newspaper in which it compared its DATE subscription rates with those of another regional newspaper , ORG . According to the advertisement , the PERSON was “ the best ” local newspaper .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG applied to ORG ( PERSON ) for a preliminary injunction ( einstweilige GPE ) under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ( PERSON gegen den unlauteren PERSON ) against the applicant company and the publisher . It requested that the applicant company and the publisher be ordered to refrain from publishing the advertisement .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a preliminary injunction against the applicant company and the publisher to preserve the status quo during the proceedings . On appeal by the applicant company and the publisher , ORG ( ORG ) quashed ORG decision . The court stated , inter alia , that the CARDINAL newspapers were competitors in the same market and for the same readership . On DATE ORG ( Oberster Gerichtshof ) , on appeal by ORG , issued a preliminary injunction . The court found that the advertisement was misleading . It considered that ORG was a “ quality newspaper ” and the PERSON was not , and that this difference was not necessarily known to readersNeue GPE “ the best ” local newspaper amounted to disparagement of ORG .

CARDINAL . In the main proceedings which followed , ORG ordered the applicant company and the publisher to refrain from publishing the advertisement as long as it did not provide at the same time information which made it possible to avoid any generally pejorative value statement or any other risk of misleading readers . Secondly , it ordered them not to refer to the sales price of ORG as “ expensive ” . Thirdly , it ordered them to refrain from comparing the sales prices of the CARDINAL newspapers unless they indicated at the same time the differences in their respective reporting styles , in particular as regards coverage of foreign or domestic politics , economy , culture , science , health , environmental issues and law , and referred also to the PERSON as an entertainment - orientated communications medium and ORG as a medium mainly geared to information . Lastly , it ordered them to publish the decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , allowing in part an appeal by the applicant company and the publisher , confined the third branch of the injunction to the order that the applicant company and the publisher refrain from comparing the sales prices of the CARDINAL newspapers without indicating the differences in their reporting styles as regards coverage of foreign or domestic politics , economy , culture , science , health , environmental issues and law . It confirmed the lower court 's decision as to the remaining branches of the injunction . The court considered that it was a matter of common knowledge that both newspapers were competing in the same market . As to the differences in quality between the newspapers and the argument that readers were not familiar with these differences , ORG referred to ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company and the publisher lodged an appeal on points of law against this decision , relying on LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared their appeal on points of law inadmissible . The decision was served on the parties on DATE .
CARDINAL . The relevant sections of LAW read as follows :

“ Any person who in the course of business commits , for purposes of competition , acts contrary to honest practices , may be ordered to desist from further engaging in those acts and held liable for damages .

Any person who in the course of business , for purposes of competition , makes declarations that could be misleading about commercial conditions , especially on the quality , origin , method of production or calculation of the prices of single goods or services or the whole stock , on price - lists , about the manner and sources of supply , about the possession of awards , about the occasion or purpose of the sale or about the quantity of the stock , may be ordered to desist from further making those declarations and , if he knew or must have known that they were likely to mislead , held liable for damages . However , comparing prices in advertisements is authorised , if it is not contrary to this section or LAW . ”
